metadata.case_name: Tobacco Dealers v. State (Civil Appeals Nos. 89, 90, 126-128 of 1961)
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 89, 90 and 126 to 128 of 1961

facts.text: In 1909, Act VII of 1084 (Cochin Tobacco Act) passed by Maharaja of Cochin to consolidate and amend law relating to tobacco.
Section 4 of Cochin Act prohibited possession for sale, transport, import, export, sale and cultivation of tobacco except as permitted under Act or rules.
Section 5 of Cochin Act empowered Diwan to make rules consistent with Act to permit and regulate possession, transport, import, export, sale, cultivation of tobacco and form of duty on retail sale.

Tobacco Cultivation Rules framed under Cochin Act: prohibited cultivation except under licence in specified areas; drying, curing, manufacturing, storing under Excise supervision; licences for Rs.50 fee; harvesting, transport under permits; stock books; sale only to licensed dealers.
Additional rules under Cochin Act prohibited import/export/possession for sale except under notifications for sale shops and licences.
Pre-1950 system: auction of A class and B class shops (last auction May 30, 1919); C class shops on recommendation/payment of fee.
Similar Travancore Tobacco Regulation I of 1911 (1087 M.E.): prohibitions on cultivation etc., rules under S.31 for permitting/regulating with duty/fee.
Travancore rules (in force Apr 1, 1950): elaborate control on cultivation, curing, manufacture, bonding, licences for sales, transport, possession.
On April 1, 1950, Finance Act No. XXV of 1950 (S.11) extended Central Excises and Salt Act No.1 of 1944 to Part B State of Travancore-Cochin.
Finance Act S.13(2): repealed any corresponding law in force immediately before Apr 1, 1950.

Notification dated August 3, 1950, changed Cochin rules: abolished auction sales, introduced graded licence fees for A (stockists), B (wholesale), C (retail) class licensees; removed control on cultivation etc.
Notification dated January 25, 1951, similar change for Travancore area.
Appellants in Cochin appeals (Nos. 89,90/61) were A class licensees/tobacco dealers; filed petitions in 1956 challenging new rules as void ab initio due to repeal of Cochin Act.
Appellants in Travancore appeals (Nos.126-128/61) filed petitions in 1955.
Kerala High Court dismissed petitions on November 8, 1957, holding laws in force under List II item 62.
Appeals to Supreme Court on certificates from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Cochin Tobacco Act VII of 1084 and Travancore Tobacco Regulation I of 1911 (with rules) were laws 'corresponding to' Central Excises and Salt Act 1944, and thus repealed by S.13(2) of Finance Act 1950 from April 1, 1950.
Whether notifications of Aug 3, 1950 (Cochin) and Jan 25, 1951 (Travancore) framing new rules for graded licence fees were valid, or void ab initio for lack of supporting law.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cochin Act and Travancore Act stood repealed by Finance Act 1950 on introduction of Central Act from April 1, 1950; thus notifications framing new rules void ab initio.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Finance Act 1950 S.13(2); Central Excises and Salt Act 1944

petitioner_arguments.text: New rules invalid on various other grounds (delegation, Arts.14,19(1)(g),276(2) Constitution).

respondent_arguments.text: Cochin/Travancore Acts not repealed as not corresponding to Central Act (no excise duty on production/manufacture; licence fees/tax under List II item 60/62).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Seventh Schedule List II items 60,62; no charging section like Central Act S.3

respondent_arguments.text: Graded licence fee is sustainable tax; new rules valid under surviving Acts.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Cochin Tobacco Act S.5; Travancore Act S.31

respondent_arguments.text: No declaration needed as new rules abrogated from Jan 1958.

court_reasoning.text: Cochin and Travancore Acts with rules substantially correspond to Central Act: both control tobacco from cultivation/growth to retail sale to consumer via licensing, tracking movement; method of revenue (auctions/licence fees) is variant but essence same as excise duty realization.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correspondence if substantially provides for same matters, not complete identity; pre-Constitution states not bound by legislative lists.

court_reasoning.text: Absence of explicit charging section irrelevant: tax levied via rules under S.5 (Cochin)/S.31 (Travancore); auctions were method to realize excise revenue akin to licence fees under Central Act S.6.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Excise duty primarily on production but can be at subsequent stages; imported tobacco minor part.

court_reasoning.text: Acts repealed from Apr 1, 1950; no law to support new rules of 1950/1951 imposing tax, offends Art.265; cannot sustain under List II post-repeal.
Shah J (separate): At least licence/storage provisions correspond to Central Act S.6 and rules; to that extent repealed; new rules 14-16 invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No legislative duplication/overlapping if both in force.

holdings.text: Cochin Tobacco Act and Travancore Tobacco Regulation with rules corresponded substantially to Central Excises and Salt Act 1944 and stood repealed by Finance Act S.13(2) from April 1, 1950.
Notifications framing new rules (Aug 1950 Cochin, Jan 1951 Travancore) invalid ab initio, no force/effect.

precedents_cited.relevance: Substantial provision for same matters = correspondence for repeal; no need complete identity.

precedents_cited.relevance: Excise duty on articles produced/manufactured; primary at production stage.

precedents_cited.relevance: Excise duties on manufacture/production of commodity.

statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibited/regulated tobacco activities; empowered rules for duties/licences; repealed as corresponding.

statutes_cited.relevance: Defined/prohibited/regulated tobacco; empowered rules with duties/fees; repealed as corresponding.

statutes_cited.relevance: No tax without authority of law; adaptation of pre-Constitution laws; state taxing powers.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, set aside Kerala High Court order dated Nov 8, 1957; allowed writ petitions declaring new Tobacco Rules (notifications Aug 3, 1950 and Jan 25, 1951) invalid ab initio and without force/effect as framed without authority post-repeal of parent Acts.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that new rules invalid ab initio; relief for period rules in force post-petitions.
outcome.costs: Appellants get costs from State (one set hearing costs).

key_quotes.text: "the Cochin Act as well as the similar Travancore Act along with the Rules corresponded to the Central Act substantially and would thus be repealed by s.13(2) of the Finance Act, 1950."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on correspondence and repeal.

key_quotes.text: "There would be no power in the State Government thereafter to frame new Rules either in August 1950 or in January 1951 for there would be no law to support the new Rules and without such law the new Rules could not impose a tax as that would clearly offend Art.265."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the relevant rules made under the Travancore and the Cochin Tobacco Acts requiring licences to be taken for storage of tobacco... were law corresponding to the provisions of the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Shah J's concurring view on partial correspondence.
